body: In this, the last holiday aria of the century, New York is a town of signs and portents. It's a pre-millennial menagerie, a sideshow city, a place of small curiosities and large paradoxes. Regard the handwritten signs posted yesterday in Forbidden Planet, the science-fiction comic-book emporium on East 13th Street. Decorated with cheery plastic
title: Millennium Nigh? Well, Quit Shoving.; Christmastime Manhattan, Always Frenzied, Goes Moonstruck

body: VIEWED from the cosmopolitan cities of the north, like London and Paris, the southeastern corner of Sicily is a remote part of Europe. But in a Mediterranean context, it lies at the very heart of things. It stands sentinel between Iberia and the Middle East, closer to Tunisia in North Africa than to Rome and Naples in the boot of Italy. Geography
title: La Dolce Vita, Sicilian Style

body: Lucille Cohen, a leader among those in her residence in Coney Island, lighted the menorah on Wednesday, just as she used to do during Hanukkahs with the three daughters she raised by herself in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. But in between, there was a period of darkness that sent her life into turmoil and eventually led to a brief stay in a psychiatric
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After a Breakdown, a Place to Recover

body: Two people who tried to cross a Brooklyn street in the rain last night died after being struck by a van whose driver sped away, the police said. The victims, described by the police as a 69-year-old man and a woman believed to be his daughter, were taken to Maimonides Medical Center, where they were pronounced dead. No one was arrested and neither
title: 2 Killed in Hit-and-Run Accident in Brooklyn

body: Bishop Thomas V. Daily said yesterday that his Brooklyn diocese had experienced a ''chilling'' rash of incidents recently involving the desecration of sacred symbols, destruction of property and attempted break-ins at Roman Catholic churches. ''The violation of religious symbols held sacred by many and respected by others is marring our final
title: Bias Unit Examining Incidents At Several Catholic Churches

body: One of the first things that Nasser K. Ahmed did in his first hour of freedom last night was to pray for five minutes at the Al-Bader mosque, about a half-block from his apartment in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. ''It is a Muslim tradition,'' he explained. ''You praise God when he delivers you from trouble.'' Mr. Ahmed, 39, was allowed to leave the
title: Freedom Begins With Elation and Prayer

body: Eva S. Moskowitz, a 35-year-old former college instructor, won a lopsided victory yesterday in a City Council race representing the East Side of Manhattan. Ms. Moskowitz, a Democrat, won despite being heavily outspent in one of the costliest and hardest-fought campaigns the city has seen for a Council seat. The Fourth District race was one of
title: THE 1999 ELECTIONS: CITY COUNCIL; Though Heavily Outspent by Opponent, Democrat Wins Easily in East Side Race

body: The off-year general election is being held today, with polls open between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m. in New York City. Ballots for the city boroughs cover several judicial, Council and district attorney races, plus two proposals, one on the judiciary, the other on charter revision. Here are our recommendations: CITY COUNCIL District 4 (Manhattan's East
title: Election Day Choices in New York City

body: Candidates throughout the city spent the weekend making a barrage of telephone calls and walking through neighborhoods to urge voters to go to the polls on Tuesday for elections for several City Council seats, judgeships and district attorney positions. CITY COUNCIL -- The most hotly contested race is on the East Side of Manhattan where Eva S.
title: Candidates Vie for Council And District Attorney Slots

body: New York City's off-year election next Tuesday is expected to draw a very small turnout, which lends even more weight to every single vote. The few vigorously contested races include two for the City Council and one for Staten Island district attorney. Following are our recommendations for those races as well as for two ballot proposals. City
title: Endorsements for Tuesday's City Election

body: Turning a racist rally into a teachable moment, dozens of black families from throughout New York City brought their children yesterday for a firsthand glimpse of one of the nation's most notorious hate groups. They were among the thousands of onlookers and counterdemonstrators who surrounded the Ku Klux Klan rally on Centre Street in lower
title: Black Parents Use a Rally to Teach About a History of Hatred

body: A former cheese warehouse in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn has been converted into the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, a private, 101-pupil Quaker school for 5- to 12-year-old learning disabled children. The 17,500-square-foot, four-story late 19th-century brick structure at 20 Bergen Street, near Court Street, was gutted and all systems,
title: POSTINGS: Quakers Transform Brooklyn Cheese Warehouse; A School for Learning Disabled

body: On a September afternoon more than eight years ago, Vincent Bickelman was found dead, shot six times while on the lawn in front of his Bath Beach home, in what police described at the time as a mysterious killing. But yesterday law enforcement officials said they believed that Mr. Bickelman's fatal mistake came a month earlier when he burglarized
title: 1991 Killing Is Said To Be Revenge for Robbery of Mob Figure's Daughter

body: VOGEL-Harvey L. Age 61. Died peacefully in the presence of his family on October 9, 1999. Harvey is survived by his wife Laurie, his children Howard, Judi, Hilary, Jordan and Victoria, his brother Bruce and his aunt Ethel. A memorial service will be held at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL. Tuesday (today), 1PM. In lieu of flowers,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths VOGEL, HARVEY L.

body: This is the time when grown-ups in blue plastic helmets look perfectly normal on crowded city streets. When friends, lovers, family members and co-workers find themselves discovering ugly things about one another. When perfect strangers plunge into passionate debates at the sight of the letters N and Y. New York hasn't experienced this in a long,
title: Yankee Fans and Met Fans: Mutual Denigration Society

body: FOR the Mets at Shea Stadium in October, it's never just baseball. It's been shoe polish and pine tar, a brawl at second base, a box of scuffed balls. Now it's the mysterious ''inflammatory response'' from a cortisone shot to Mike Piazza's sprained left thumb, which benched their cleanup hitter and catcher against the Arizona Diamondbacks yesterday
title: Sports of The Times; More Mystical Success For the Mets at Shea

body: THAT other Noo Yawk baseball team reappeared last night in all its usual October splendor. You know, the one with its name on the Bronx stadium where it plays, but no names on the back of the uniforms the players wear; the one that was mostly out of sight and out of mind while the Noo Yawk team in Queens did its Lazarus impersonation. That other
title: Sports of The Times; E-Z Pass Playoff: Root for One

body: All the prayers to St. Anthony, the patron saint of miracles, paid off for Angela Frontera. Or maybe it was her son Paul's unwashed blue shirt, the same one he had sweated through on Sunday at Shea, that did the trick. Or was it his girlfriend Tara's rally cap -- a Yankee hat with the logo crossed out in red? Whatever it was, it didn't matter in
title: Mets Fans' Ride: Lighting Candles and Reaching for Antacid

body: YOU'D think he was the star of the movie, instead of the guy who rents it out at three bucks a pop. ''Marty!'' ''Marty!'' ''Marty!'' his customers cry, vying for his attention, demanding the inside cinema poop. It's elbows-out time in the video store: the cardboard covers of the latest video releases have been laid out in neat rows, two deep, on
title: Captain Video

body: NEARLY every fine Saturday and Sunday from spring to fall, some residents of Park Slope, Brooklyn, change personality, as if howling at the sun. Lawyers, therapists and other professionals empty their basements' contents onto stoops and sidewalks, then hawk them with the brashness of carnival barkers. ''It's a way of life in this area,'' said
title: MAKING IT WORK; Where Profits Are Incidental

body: Before Howard J. Rubenstein's party was over, the Mayor proclaimed him the world's ''dean of damage control.'' Leona M. Helmsley kissed him wetly. The Governor said New York was blessed to have him. The Duchess of York credited him with having given new meaning to her entire life. Manhattan real estate figures whispered about his Solomonic wisdom.
title: Image Spinner at the Center of a Web; Rubenstein, 'Dean of Damage Control' for New York's Powerful

body: IT'S starting to bug Marcia Tucker, all these people wanting to know what she plans to do after she packs up her office next month at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, which she founded and has embodied for the last 22 years. ''This young woman at the front desk said people come in and ask her what I'm going to do,'' said Ms. Tucker, letting
title: PUBLIC LIVES; After a Life in Art, a Quest for the Art of Life

body: A RAW octopus resting on ice at the seafood store is definitely the ugliest thing in the vicinity -- nothing like the many-hued snappers or even the white, pristine cleaned squid. No, this floppy, gray, suction-cupped monster seems to have been born with a natural defense aimed directly at the home cook. ''I am,'' it growls, ''too hideous to eat.''
title: Embracing The Octopus, Tenderly

body: Working in his cluttered principal's office at a table piled high with memos, stacks of school schedules and blueprints for the library renovation, Ron Attivissimo should have looked like a man under siege the other day. A desperate mother wanted to speak to him about transferring her daughter to his already overcrowded school, James Peter Sinnott
title: The Frantic Final Days Before School; Long Before Doors Open, a Principal Is Busy Juggling Crises

body: From time to time in the course of ''Family Values: The Mob and the Movies,'' it is stipulated that most Italian-Americans are honest, hard-working and as averse to violence as other citizens. But this documentary is not a production of some Italian-American Anti-Defamation League. No sooner is ethnic etiquette out of the way than the program
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; So It's Only Make-Believe. Gotta Problem With That?

body: Ten years ago tomorrow, Moses Stewart lost his child to one of New York City's most wrenching hate crimes. His son, Yusuf Hawkins, then 16, was attacked by a mob of bat-wielding white youths and shot to death in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. ''It's very hard to watch your children die,'' Mr. Stewart said yesterday, in an emotional speech to
title: Recalling Yusuf Hawkins And Hate That Killed Him

body: GERSTEN-Marvin. He was a father, a husband, a hilarious, incredibly generous, ultra-charismatic, whip-smart and very good looking man. Marvin Gersten died comfortably in his home, at the age of 60, of malignant melanoma, August 10, 1999, surrounded by his family. A self-made man, Marvin grew up in Bensonhurst. He worked his way through City College
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GERSTEN, MARVIN

body: Gooey. Viscous. Steamy. Torrid. Pick your adjective. No matter how you put it, it was hot again yesterday. For a second straight day, the temperature climbed to 98 degrees, and remarkably empty streets throughout the city suggested that most New Yorkers were staying as far indoors as possible. Even the hardy old men who are usually fixtures in
title: When It's 98 Degrees Outdoors, Staying Indoors Is the Best Escape

body: An off-duty detective from the Bronx Street Crime Unit was arrested in Rockland County Thursday night after his car ran down two 15-year-old girls, leaving them critically injured, and he subsequently refused to take a breath screening test, officials said yesterday. Late Thursday, the New York City police suspended the detective, Michael J. Foley,
title: Off-Duty Detective Charged In Accident Injuring 2 Girls

body: It's been so hot over the last two days that Joseph Ponte, 84, couldn't catch his breath in his apartment even with the help of an oxygen tank. Anthony Caputo, 84, fainted in his bathroom after his air-conditioner began to falter. And Henry Fox, 79, could not help but recall the days during World War II when he would fry eggs on the deck of his
title: A HEAT WAVE SIZZLES: THE SCENE; A Place to Cool Off

body: ON paper, Richard T. Santulli seemed an unlikely candidate to revolutionize the elite business of owning private jets. Raised in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, where his family lived with one set of grandparents and across the street from the other, he did not take his first plane flight until his honeymoon in 1966. Now, at 54, he travels worldwide, is
title: PRIVATE SECTOR; Private Jets for (More of) the People

body: Fred C. Trump, one of the last of New York City's major postwar builders, died yesterday at a hospital in Queens. He was 93 and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Although Mr. Trump was stricken with Alzheimer's disease six years ago, he still retained his title of chairman of the board of Trump Management, a title he held since the company was
title: Fred C. Trump, Postwar Master Builder of Housing for Middle Class, Dies at 93

body: A 32-year-old man was shot dead behind the wheel of his car in Brooklyn early yesterday after what the police called a minor dispute over double parking. The victim, Chun-Man Sze of Bensonhurst, was shot once in the chest by the passenger of a dark-colored Jeep Cherokee, the police said. Mr. Sze was returning from a fishing trip on Long Island
title: Brooklyn Man Is Fatally Shot in His Car in a Dispute Over Parking

author: Margaret Mittelbach and Michael Crewdson are the authors of ''Wild New York: A Guide to the Wildlife, Wild Places and the Natural Phenomena of New York City.''
body: It's easy to be dazzled by speed. Man o' War. Secretariat. Citation. And Hercules, one of the fastest of them all. Granted, most people haven't heard of Hercules or how fast he is. It's probably because he's a pigeon. Trained to ''home'' to his loft in Coney Island, Hercules can reach speeds of 70 miles per hour with the wind at his tail. Every
title: Odyssey of Homing: Tender Care Yields One Tough Racer

body: LIKE it's namesake, Bath, the spa town in England, Bath Beach is a tranquil place. But it is no longer the resort area it was a century ago. The beach itself was eradicated in a postwar building boom, and largely replaced by housing on a landfill. Now it is primarily residential with a walkway along the waterfront and a view of Coney Island across
title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Bath Beach, Brooklyn; Once a Bayfront Resort, Now Residential

body: Like countless other New York City parents, Nancy Gasparino and her husband, Frank, a firefighter, have considered moving from their home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to the suburbs. But over the past few years, with crime falling and the economy booming, they have made their fragile peace with the city. These days, however, the thought of fleeing New
title: Between the Feuding Rudys; Parents Like Giuliani and Crew, but Fear for the Schools

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Greenpoint to Sheepshead Bay: When the Boards Meet

body: MARANA JARAMILLO did not need to fuss with a menu when she sat down for a Mother's Day dinner last Sunday at Salinas, an Ecuadorean restaurant in Park Slope. She knew exactly what she wanted: the papas con cuy, or potatoes with guinea pig. ''It's a special day for mothers, and this is a special plate,'' said Ms. Jaramillo, 50, who grew up in
title: MAKING IT WORK; Not For The Faint Of Palate

body: Although his head is covered with gray hair and his stride has become a little stiff, there is a youthful glow that comes over Tommy Davis's face when he remembers his prowess as a batter in the major leagues -- a baseball career that lasted 18 years and included play for 10 different teams, including the world champion Los Angeles Dodgers in 1963.
title: New Life for an Old Favorite; The Spaldeen, Stickball's Bouncy Foundation, Makes a Comeback

body: CHERRYL MITCHELL is a native New Yorker, born and raised in Brooklyn. But she's quick to tell you she doesn't think much of life in the city, or the ''concrete forest,'' as she calls it. ''I left and I've never missed it or looked back,'' she said. ''Now I hear birds and see real trees when I wake up.'' While there are trees in Brooklyn, and birds,
title: Life on the Edge; How High a Fence Is the City Line?

body: Seeking to address complaints that his $11 billion, five-year school construction plan did not do enough to reduce severe overcrowding in Queens, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed the addition of 10,650 seats for the borough over the number he called for in his November plan. In sweetening his initial proposal, which promised the borough
title: Crew Offers More Schools For Queens

body: ON his rare forays into the hinterlands, John Franco has made an amazing discovery. The pizza is not as good in the suburbs, and neither is the bread. It's a fact. Something about being outside the five boroughs curdles the dough, or spoils it, or whatever it is that goes wrong with dough. For that reason alone, Franco cannot leave. He is a true
title: Sports of The Times; John Franco Savors His Home Plate

body: MARTINO-Leonard D., 69. Died on April 6. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., he lived in Hohokus, NJ for the last 3 years. He retired in 1996 after a career of 52 years in the printing industry, where he was Production Manager of Skillcraft Inc. in Manhattan. He served in the Army during the Korean conflict, in Germany, attaining the rank of Corporal. Later he
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MARTINO, LEONARD D.

body: THIS story starts with the heel spur, the one in Joe DiMaggio's right foot, that sidelined him for 65 games in the Yankees' 1949 season and then sent him, 41 years later, to the office of Dr. Rock G. Positano, a foot and ankle specialist at the Hospital for Special Surgery. Dr. Positano treats ''pretty much anybody who's anybody,'' as he puts it,
title: Late to DiMaggio Orbit, but Staging Send-Off

body: It was a hazy early morning in this glitzy desert kingdom, and Simon Crisford and Saeed bin Suroor were staring silently at the last turn of their mile-and-an-eighth training track. The object of their attention soon came into view, his pulsing chest dark with sweat: Worldly Manner, the bay brown colt that they hope will make racing history as the
title: HORSE RACING; Far From Bluegrass, Dubai Runs Stealthily for the Roses

body: WHEN Leonard Riggio was a night student at New York University, he coped with the droning tedium of business lectures by snatching a strategic seat behind a student with a broad back and, he says, losing himself in the pages of the ''History of the Peloponnesian War.'' He found the classes in business policy and management so dull, in fact, that he
title: Trying to Read a Hazy Future; Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief

body: HE still dresses as if he is going to dinner with Brooke Astor, who by the way sent him ''the nicest note'' the other day. He is still courtly, elegant, fussy, decent and remote. But today, when David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor, takes his place as expected in the front lines of a large rally for police reform alongside his combustible former
title: PUBLIC LIVES; The Still-Dignified but Angrier Ex-Mayor

body: LIEUT. ERIC ADAMS'S police career began with a beating. His own. He was 15 and had a nose for trouble, which was easy enough to find in South Jamaica, Queens, where his mother met the mortgage payments and raised six children cleaning houses by day and office buildings by night. Lieutenant Adams was the kind of child who ''wore my mother's knees
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Behind a Badge, Confronting Issues of Race

body: A Brooklyn man who was acquitted of murder but convicted of weapons possession in the highly publicized killing of a black teen-ager 10 years ago was charged yesterday with racketeering and other crimes that prosecutors said he has committed more recently as an associate of organized crime. The man, Joseph Serrano, 29, was one of seven people,
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Brooklyn Man Faces Racketeering Charges

body: Federal agents found several human bones yesterday while digging in a Livingston, N.J., backyard for the remains of a Russian boxer who vanished from the streets of Brooklyn in 1995. Though investigators said they believed they had found the body of the boxer, Sergei Kobozev, they said a positive identification might not be possible for several
title: Investigators Unearth Bones That May Be Remains of Missing Russian Boxer

body: Daily demonstrations planned for outside the Brooklyn court where jury selection is to begin today in the trial of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima could increase the chance that the trial will be delayed or moved out of New York City, lawyers for two of the officers said yesterday. The lawyers said that the
title: Protests May Disrupt Louima Trial, Lawyers Say

body: Hoping to purge the last remnants of mob involvement in the garbage hauling industry, the city intends to refuse licenses to more than 70 haulers for showing a lack ''of honesty, integrity and good character,'' a regulator said Friday. The companies now pick up trash from businesses ranging from skyscrapers to corner stores. ''We're coming to the
title: City May Refuse Licenses To Over 70 Trash Haulers

body: Some residents of Bensonhurst are voicing fear that a proposed theater complex with up to 16 screens, 3,500 seats, 700 parking spaces and retail stores will snarl traffic and increase pollution in the neighborhood. And people who live in apartment buildings on Cropsey Avenue are expressing worry that congestion from the Bayside Cinema, at 25th
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; To Some, Cinema Complex Is Not a Coming Attraction

body: THE Village of Lynbrook, an older suburb with a venerable rail link to Brooklyn that lured early commuters, has aged gracefully, like an old shoe of high quality. It is comfortable, scuffed here and there, but too solidly prosperous to be down at the heel. Good schools and ample rail service enhance this Nassau County community on Long Island's
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Lynbrook, N.Y.; 'Down-Home' Village on the South Shore

body: A self-employed livery-cab driver was stabbed to death yesterday morning in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn by three men who were trying to rob him, the police said. The driver, Mohammed Hanif, a 40-year-old immigrant from Pakistan, was dropping off three passengers at the corner of Washington and Flushing Avenues in Brooklyn when they tried
title: Cabdriver, 40, Is Stabbed to Death in Brooklyn During an Attempted Robbery

body: GERSHMAN-Frank. Died March 15th, 1999 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Devoted father of Marvin Gershman, Helen Meade and Albert Gershman. Dear grandfather of Paul and Steven Meade, Amy, Daniel and Andrew Gershman. Lifelong and dedicated member of the Jewish Community Center of Bensonhurst. Over 50-year member of the Independent
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GERSHMAN, FRANK

body: AN arc of gray seagulls banked against a cold gust of wind and wheeled high above Brighton Beach toward the Atlantic Ocean. Sofia Garber followed the birds with her big blue eyes and pulled the fur collar of her coat to her cheeks. Standing on an expanse of boardwalk between a line of apartment buildings and the sand, Ms. Garber, 51, reflected on
title: From Brighton Beach to America; The Wave of Immigrants Began 25 Years Ago. Soon Russian Filled the Streets. Now, the Tide Is Ebbing.

body: The body of a 19-year-old Baruch College student was discovered Friday night inside a trash-filled shaftway at the campus, four days after a fellow student had reported seeing a woman leap from an overhead window , the police said yesterday. Campus security guards found the body of the student, Yankum Huang, at 9:45 P.M., a little more than an hour
title: Body of Missing Student Is Discovered in Search of Shaftway

body: The police are searching for a 19-year-old student at Baruch College who set off for school Monday and never returned home. The woman, Yankum Huang, was last seen by a friend that morning as she changed trains at the Pacific Street subway station in Brooklyn, the police said. Ms. Huang, a sophomore in the liberal arts program, lives with her family
title: Baruch College Student From Brooklyn Is Missing

body: Fernando Leon, this numbers runner with the nickname Benny tattooed on his arm, was getting madder and madder at Grace Meullins. The woman kept bothering him for the $700 that she said he owed her daughter. Then she hit him over the head with a flashlight. ''He stewed over it and he was drinking,'' Ronald Balzan, a homicide detective, remembered
title: Detectives in Hot Pursuit Of Homicides Grown Cold; Squad Combines DNA and Shoe Leather To Crack Old Cases With Loose Ends

body: A construction worker who the police said was distraught at being dismissed from his job fired a single shot into a wall of a Rockefeller Center construction site yesterday, but no one was injured. The worker, Thomaso Spatola, 36, fled on the subway but was later arrested as he approached his home in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, the police said. He was
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Man Held in Shooting At Rockefeller Job Site

body: BAYSIDE Music of Dorsey Brothers Evokes 40's in the 90's The 1940's will merge with 1990's multimedia today with ''Big Band '99: The Fabulous Dorseys,'' a matinee performance at Queensborough Community College. The show will feature the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra, conducted by the trombonist Jim Miller; the vocalist Nancy Knorr, the Pied Pipers
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: The special election this week to fill open seats on the City Council produced three new members who are at the bottom of the seniority list. But, because of the impact of term limits, if the freshmen are able to retain their seats over the next four years they will be the Council's most senior members. The election on Tuesday also revealed some
title: Term Law Could Aid Council's Newest

body: Christine Quinn, the former executive director of the New York Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, handily won a special election yesterday to fill the City Council seat on the West Side of Manhattan vacated by State Senator Thomas K. Duane. That race was one of three contests yesterday for open seats on the City Council. In Brooklyn, Michael C.
title: Gay-Rights Advocate Wins Village Seat

body: Candidates in three boroughs spent the weekend making a barrage of telephone calls and walking through neighborhoods to urge voters to go to the polls tomorrow in a special election to fill City Council seats in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island. In Manhattan, four candidates are running for the Third Council District seat vacated by Thomas K.
title: Special Election Will Decide 3 City Council Seats

body: New York City will hold a special election tomorrow to replace three City Council members who have moved on to other posts. The winners must all stand for re-election this fall. If they keep their seats, they have a chance to develop substantial influence in a body where most incumbents must leave office in 2001, when term limits kick in. District
title: City Council Endorsements

body: NOT long before their daughter Rosetta's wedding, Maria and Louis Guttadauro of Borough Park began looking for a pair of houses to buy alongside each other in the neighborhood where the families could live snugly. What they found was discouraging. ''It was too expensive,'' Mrs. Guttadauro said. ''We couldn't afford to buy a second house in Borough
title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Borough Park, Brooklyn; For Many Orthodox Jews, a Heartland

body: Kevin Chalmers started kindergarten in September 1993 and was thrown out the same month, after he cursed at his teacher, overturned chairs and bit the principal. Kevin, who is now 11, said in a recent interview that his rage was misplaced. But he certainly had a lot to be angry about. Kevin was born with traces of cocaine and heroin in his
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Sense of Belonging Heals an Angry Child

body: Police officers in the bomb squad rushed to a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday afternoon to remove two grenades that a resident had found in his new home. The man, whose name was withheld by the police, found the grenades when he moved into the apartment at 1799 West Third Street in Bensonhurst about a month ago, said Detective Robert Samuel,
title: 2 Grenades Found in Brooklyn Apartment

body: When a single Ku Klux Klan flier surfaced recently, the reaction was big and swift: a community meeting, plans for a youth conference, and a proposal for a neighborhood fair. One brochure might not have generated such a response in another neighborhood. But this was Bensonhurst, where nearly 10 years ago Yusef K. Hawkins was murdered by a white mob
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; A Hint of the Klan, and a Community Hits Back Hard

body: After two community boards of adjacent districts in Brooklyn permitted a total of 41 block parties on the same Saturday last August, fire chiefs grew alarmed by the concentration of so many sealed-off streets. ''They realized that this presented a problem if there was a fire or a heart attack,'' said Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington. ''Too many block
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Wrong Decision on a Rite of Summer, Districts Say

body: ALL the boys were talking about her hip-revealing Gucci skirt, as she swirled around the dance floor to the pounding beat of a Puff Daddy CD with her best girlfriend from school. The guys gaped at Nicky Hilton, a tall size 0 blonde, whose waist and shoulders also played peekaboo in a black tube top, as she tugged on her Patricia Field cowboy hat,
title: A Sweet-16-Going-On-25 Party

body: After Hyman Itzkowitz suffered a debilitating stroke 10 years ago, his wife, Helen, devoted herself to caring for him. Day and night. Mr. Itzkowitz was mentally sharp; he followed the stock market and the fortunes of the Yankees. Yet he could not care for himself. Mrs. Itzkowitz washed, dressed, fed and shaved him daily. The couple had been married
title: The Neediest Cases; Support Group Eases Strain of Caring for a Loved One

body: The coming special election for a City Council seat in Staten Island is supposed to be a nonpartisan affair, with candidates not allowed to run under the labels of the major political parties. But the race in the 50th Council District, which also includes a slice of Brooklyn, has been very much a battle between the Democratic and Republican
title: Staten Island Council Contest Is Nonpartisan (Theoretically)

body: On a recent sun-splashed afternoon, Representative Jerrold L. Nadler was standing outside an auditorium at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan when a lanky woman with frizzy brown hair strode out of the crowd and gushed, ''Can I just give you a hug? ''What you have been doing is just magnificent,'' she continued. ''You're the only one
title: Finding Stardom in a Supporting Role; Nadler's Defense of Clinton Lifts His Profile in the House and at Home

body: There is no one associated with organized crime who doesn't believe that Gotti ordered Castellano's death. Joseph Castellano, whose life was turned inside out by the murder, says he doesn't believe it. ''I know they say that Mr. Gotti'' -- he is careful to employ the honorific -- ''was the one who murdered our father,'' he told me recently. ''But I
title: The Don Is Done

body: Even more than politics, all crime is local. The news from the Police Department that New York had fewer reported killings in 1998 than in 1964 may hold little comfort for someone who was mugged or whose car was stolen last year. When it comes to personal safety, criminologists note, perception often lags behind reality. Just how safe are
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Crime Count: Which Areas Are Safest?

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday described a plan to create five new subway routes under Second Avenue as ''something of a pipe dream,'' and said the city should first extend the No. 7 subway line to the site on Manhattan's West Side where he wants a football stadium built. The proposal, which is to be formally announced later this month by the
title: Mayor Urges West Side Subway Extension, Not East Side Line

body: Katherine Cocivera professed not to like mangoes. ''My mommy doesn't give me that,'' the 4-year-old huffed. ''My mommy gives me Tater Tots.'' But when the exotic fruit with the strong flavor was disguised -- blended with mashed sweet potatoes in a filling topped with toasted coconut and baked with an almond crust -- she said, ''That tasted good.''
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; Broccoli for Young Palates

body: They are as different as the games they play. They sit side by side on the motor coach rumbling down the Garden State Parkway, the 75-year-old widower who travels here to shoot craps all night, up to five times a week, and the 53-year-old woman with a Jamaican accent who dabbles in slots a few times a year on days off from her job sorting medical
title: Buses and Bets: A Way of Life; Despite Crashes, the Ride Is Part of the Casino Outing
